heading: A Man Before His Time
content:
The full Safari engine is inside of iPhone. And so, you can write amazing [web] apps that look exactly and behave exactly like apps on the iPhone. And these apps can integrate perfectly with iPhone services. They can make a call, they can send an email, they can look up a location on Google Maps.

Steve Jobs
2007 Apple Worldwide Developer Conference

• The iPhone is introduced
  • All native apps developed by Apple
  • All third-party apps must be web apps

• Apple releases a software development kit for third parties to build native iPhone apps
  • The App Store goes live
  • Fruit Ninja takes over the world

heading: The Upside of Native Apps
content:
• Better access to device features
  • Higher perceived performance
  • Offline functionality
  • Re-engageable (updates and alerts via notifications)
  • App stores provide discoverability and a path for monetization

heading: The Downside of Native Apps
content:
• Apps must be downloaded and installed
  • Multiple platforms mean heavy development costs
  • Complicated and tedious app store approval process

heading: The Upside of Web Apps
content:
• Universal, can run on any browser or device
  • Build for one platform (the web)
  • No lengthy download/install
  • No app store approval process

heading: The Downside of Web Apps
content:
• Limited access to device features (historically)
  • No offline access
  • Must support many browsers and browser versions
  • No app store, so discoverability is reduced
  • Harder to monetize

heading: What the Devil is a PWA?
content:
• A buzzword
  • A website, enhanced
  • A set of principles to optimize a website reliable, fast, and engaging
  • A spectrum of web technologies that shrink the gap between a web app and a native app

heading: Standard Traits
content:
• Secure
  • Responsive
  • Progressive
  • Evergreen
  • Linkable

heading: Secure
content:
• Website is served over a secure, encrypted connection (SSL)
  • Basic requirement for PWA other technologies to function

heading: Responsive
content:
• Website layout, content and features adapt to any screen size and device
  • Mobile-friendly and touch-friendly

heading: Progressive
content:
• Website functions on any browser and device
  • Enhanced features and functionality are activated for more-capable browsers and devices

heading: Evergreen
content:
• Users always have the latest version of the website
  • Website updates itself automatically when a network connection is present

heading: Linkable
content:
• Easily share the app via a URL
  • Bypass app store
  • Deep-linking to interior pages
  • URL should indicate the current state of the application, allowing it to be retained/reloaded

heading: Advanced Traits
content:
• Feels like an app
  • Installable
  • Connectivity-independent
  • Discoverable
  • Re-engageable

heading: Feel Link an App
content:
• Frameless, full-screen browser experience
  • App shell that loads quickly and can be cached
  • Functionality is separated from content
  • Minimal page refreshes

heading: Installable
content:
• Users can easily install a shortcut to the website on their home screen
  • Developers have control over how their website appears and how it can be launched
    • Display name and icon of the installed shortcut
    • Orientation (portrait, landscape)
    • Full-screen, no browser chrome

heading: Connectivity-independent
content:
• Website should work on low-quality networks or offline
  • Control what is shown to users when no connectivity
  • Cache-first networking
  • Content is separated from the app frame, can be refreshed when connectivity improves

heading: Discoverable
content:
• Websites should identify themselves to search engines as an application that can be cataloged and ranked
  • App directories are emerging
  • PWA's are appearing alongside native apps in some app stores

heading: Re-engageable
content:
• Website should be able to re-engage with the user, even when it is not currently in use
  • The new Push Notifications API allows a website to send notifications to a user’s device
